Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Margaret Smith
Address: 1281 Lea St North, Battleford
Birthplace: Scotland

1. HOUSEHOLD DETAILS
   - What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
   - Where did you set up housekeeping? Home Street, 30 miles from N Battleford
   - How many people did you prepare meals? 10 children & adults
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 50 miles
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? 3-4 months
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour rolled out, sugar tea coffee jam & syrup rice & barley

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Later on
     Fire Roses flour
   - In what quantities did you buy it? Five to six sacks
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $5.00
   - How much did you use rye flour? None to get
   - Whole wheat flour? None
   - Was flour milled locally? No... how far away? 30... that year? Miles
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.85 100 lbs
   - What other grain products did you use? None
   - Cornmeal? No... Whole wheat? No... Farina? No
   - Other?
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes later on
   - How did you grind it? By our own homemade mill
Smith, Mrs. Margaret
1081 George St.
North Battleford

How did you preserve meat? (Canned it when we could)
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? (1912)

For how long?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? (Fresh)
Kinds? (White fish)

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

The first year none.

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? We never had any.

Could you get potatoes at the store? None at that time.

If not, where from? No, nowhere but we bought them from home.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of 1938?

Potatoes $1.00. Cabbage $1.00. Carrots $1.00. Onions $1.00.

Turnips $1.00. Beets $1.00.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? None.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.

What weight? 10 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? In a box.

What was the price of prunes? $2.00.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

Apricots & raisins main fruit.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? No. Corn? No. Beans? No. Saskatoons? $2.00.

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

What year did you first preserve meat by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Not till later years did we can anything to can.

To what extent? We canned when we had.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

16. **SHAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the shappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

As far as I can remember all we got was in paper. E.g., 1907-1909.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

The day's menu was everyday breakfast porridge twice or three times a week for dinner. Porridge at night. Bread & syrup or jam was our main meals apart from porridge no milk for a year. Ages 8-10-12-14 years.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? _________________. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Our first Xmas dinner was in our own sod house 1906-6 no one but ourselves.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No I can't say we were near starvation. We was very tired & syrup & poor jam. We we got along somehow we got a cows head from a farmer to make head cheese & thought that wonderful.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the name and list the members of the family living at that time. Also give the approximate number of people in each meal.

The day's menu was every day before breakfast, lunch & dinner.

Porridge or oatmeal & bread for dinner.

We had our meals in our own home for a year—after 8-10-12-14 years.

18. What food did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Kentucky?

Our house 1906 & no one but ourselves.

19. Here you may explain to almost starvation. Tell us how you got by without food. Give details.

No meat, no eggs, no milk, no flour.

We used newspapers & paper bags.

We got along by borrowing from a farmer & making bread from flour & sugar.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

As far as I am concerned there is no comparison we had a tough time of it for a few years coming from a city like Edinburgh where we had all we could eat.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

When the C.M.R. & the C.P.R. tracks were laid 1907-8 I think they brought these goods from Battleford & we relied on them to bring us a few messages thru but we only began to live when we got a few cows milk & butter which is the main things we missed.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

We arrived in N.Battleford in April 1906 then got to Eagle Hills after getting here & wagons parked at the Battle river while we got all we needed in that way & got snowed up for several day in the Pikes Journals landed on the Provo 5th of May in another snowstorm so you may presume did not feel very elated & had to get a tent up whatever nothing but rolling prairie which had just been turned & was a sorry sight there was enough paper for me to describe all I could of this & the lasting memory can remember as I am 83 years old & a long jump from then to now by Smith.

Gave us a new measure truly but we only

22. Plans and other details from your family's records of hunting experiences.

We arrived in Battleford in April 1906
then for 8 weeks lived after getting there we camped
packed at the Platte river which was far all our
received in that area & for several weeks of 1906
personal dogs in the field generally traveled on
the prairie for 3 days in another formation
to homestead purchase the most feet away
of town & then to get a rent up mortgage
no matter but really Bronze which
Road first been himself was a story right
there was no place for me & Victoria
all I needed & then the best my memory
can remember as of an 83 year old & a
long family from then & now
